title: 107_hr2252
content: The Act titled "Conduit Contribution Prevention Act of 2001" increases penalties for violations of conduit contribution ban. The Act "Conduit Contribution Prevention Act of 2001" increases civil and criminal penalties for knowing and willful violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Civil penalties are now not less than 300 percent of the amount involved in the violation and not more than the greater of $50,000 or 1000 percent of the amount involved. Criminal penalties have also been increased for such violations. The Act "Conduit Contribution Prevention Act of 2001" increases penalties for violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Any person who knowingly commits a violation involving $1,000 or more may face fines, imprisonment for up to 2 years, or both. The fine must be at least 300 percent of the amount involved, not exceeding $50,000 or 1000 percent of the violation amount. The United States Sentencing Commission will establish guidelines for these penalties. The United States Sentencing Commission will establish guidelines for penalties for violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, considering variations in the contribution amount. The guideline must be promulgated within 90 days of the Act's enactment, following specified procedures. The amendments made by this section to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 include mandatory referral to the Attorney General for violations of section 320 and an extension of the statute of limitations to 5 years for such violations. These amendments apply to violations occurring after the enactment of the Act. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to extend the ban on foreign contributions to all campaign-related disbursements, including those to political committees and for independent expenditures. The amendments apply to disbursements made after the enactment of this Act.
